dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A TV screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Full ashtrays, glasses, empty bottles etc. We see a MAN.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Are you there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Citroen. INT, ANDREW'S HOUSE” - STUDY - DUSK 5 A photograph. MAGGIE and ANDREW high up in the Lake District, laughing. A shadow, or reflection on the glass obscures MAGGIE's face.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: I know you're there.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE 0/S
dialogues.text: (through loudspeaker) I'm here alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MILO pouring wine into MAGGIE's glass. She raises the glass to her lips, looking at him, and sips the wine. Here, as throughout, we shoot over her shoulder, or in such a way as to conceal her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANDREW watching the TV.  10 a1 12 13 14 15 16

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A photograph of MAGGIE and ANDREW in a swimming pool looking up at the Camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Citroen driving through a village street.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE 0/S
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: I want to talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAGGIE is in bed asleep. MILO leans over her, her eyes open, she smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Citroen at the gates of a drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CCTV monitor on the wall (or on Andrew's laptop computer), shows the Citroen turning into the drive. ANDREW stands.

dialogues.speaker: MONITOR
dialogues.text: The Citroen turns into the drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights go out in the Nightclub. One spotlight is left on the dance floor.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE 0/S
dialogues.text: Walk onto the dance floor and stand in the light.  17 18 19 20 2i 22 23 24 The MAN does so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANDREW turns off the TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Citroen's point of view. The house is Georgian, tall and elegant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the CCTV monitor, or laptop computer, we see the Citroen driving slowly towards the house. 17 18 19

dialogues.speaker: MONITOR
dialogues.text: The Citroen driving” slowly towards the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MILO and MAGGIE kissing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANDREW watches the CCTV/laptop image.

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY MONITOR
dialogues.text: The Citroen parks in front of the house. A silver Mercedes 600 stands there. The Citroen parks by it. A Man gets out of the car and walks towards the door. Doorbell. 21 22 23

dialogues.speaker: MONITOR
dialogues.text: Action as above.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MILO's back. ANDREW opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Andrew Wyke?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: I'm Milo Tindle.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Oh yes. Good. Glad to meet you. He offers his hand.,MILO takes it.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You got the train to Charlebury, did you?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: I drove.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Oh, you drove?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: That's my car.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: What, the little one?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Not the big one.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: No. The big one's mine. What do you think of it?

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Very handsome.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: It is, isn't it? Come in.  26 27

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They come in. ANDREW closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Didn't hear you arrive. I was watching the video of one of my books on television. MILO stops and stares. INT, ANDREW'S HOUSE - DUSK: MILO'S Pov. 27 The interior design of the house is in total contrast to the classic Georgian facade. It is sharply contemporary: polished wooden floors, no carpets, chrome surfaces, steel and iron verticals, an elevator in a glass case, a curved staircase. A skylight, high up.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Like the house?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Extraordinary.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: You know who designed it? You know who the interior decorator was?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Yes. Your wife.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: You knew.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Yes. I knew.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I'll show you around later. You good in elevators?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Like not safe in taxis. Sorry. (he laughs) Only joking. Have a drink. I'm drinking vodka.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scotch, please.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Milo. What an interesting name. You're a foreigner, I take it.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: My father is Italian.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Milo sounds Hungarian.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Does it?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Here's your scotch. Cheers.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Cheers. « ANDREW You're sure your father isn't Hungarian?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Well, if he is he's kept it a dead secret for years. MILO sits and drinks.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: And your mother?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: English.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: So you're a kind of half breed? Sit down .

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Thanks for agreeing to see me.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Not at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know you wrote plays for television?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I don't. I write crime novels. You must know that.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: I had heard.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: But sometimes they're adapted for television by other people. You know what the word adapted means, I take it?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Adapted?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Yes. They may not have such a word in Italian.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: I speak English.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Oh good. Come and have a look at my special bookcase. ANDREW presses a button on his remote control. A wall moves and turns, revealing a bookcase.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: These are all my novels. You've read them, I suppose? MILO. Afraid not.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: No? Good God. What about this one? ‘Rat in a Trap'.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'The Obelisk'?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: ‘Dead Fish'?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: "Blackout '?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Afraid not.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: You're one in a million.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Am I? .

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Absolutely. I'm very popular. See this shelf. Translations. German, French, Dutch --

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: You speak Dutch yourself, do you?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Yes. How did you know? I have a Dutch uncle.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Can't see any Italian translations.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: No. They're a funny lot, the Italians. Culture isn't really their thing.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Their salami is good, though.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Oh is it?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Italian salami. Best in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you bring any with you?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: No. I left it at home.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Shame.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: We're going to have it for supper tonight, with a couple of bottles of Valpolicella.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: We?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Maggie and me.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Ah. Your glass is empty. What are you drinking. Vodka?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Scotch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANDREW pours two drinks.

dialogues.speaker: MILO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I want to come to the point.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Point? What point?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Are you going to give Maggie a divorce? And if not why not?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Yes, yes, we'll come to that.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: She thinks you're being unreasonable. So do I. She's never coming back to you, so why not give her the divorce?  10.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I think it’'1l do her good to wait five years. Good for her character.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: You're going to make her wait five years?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: That's the law. The law of the land.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: But that's pure spite.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Anyway, we'll come back to it. Perhaps. Have your drink first. ANDREW gives MILO his drink.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What do you do, by the way?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: I'm an actor.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Good God, are you really? I thought Maggie said you were a hairdresser.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: She must have been talking about someone else.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: You mean another friend?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Another friend?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: She tends to have more than one friend.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Does she?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Oh yes.  11.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: I'm her only friend.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: She must be lonely.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: She's not.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Acting is a pretty precarious profession isn't it? What are you acting in at the moment?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: I'm out of work.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Poor chap.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: I drive cars now and again. Chauffeuring.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Tough life.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: I keep my head above water.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: What kind of parts do you play?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Killers mostly. Sex maniacs. Perverts.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: But you seem so charming.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Yes. I know. Anyway, what about this divorce? What's your position exactly?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: All in good time. I want to check something out first. ANDREW presses a button on his remote control. A wall moves and discloses another room.  31

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANDREW walks into the room, this sequence, we are aware of the exterior light finally fading to Night.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: How do you like it?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: My study. This is where I write my best selling books. MILO looks around the room. MILO sits. » MILO Cosy.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Take a seat. Make yourself comfortable.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I understand you're fucking my wife.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Right. Yes. Right. So we've cleared that up.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: We have.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I thought you might have denied it.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Why would I deny it? followed by MILO. During  13.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Well, she is my wife.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Yes, but she's fucking me.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Oh, she's fucking you too? Well I'll be buggered--sorry!

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Yes, it's mutual.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: You take turns, do you?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: We fuck each other. That's what people do.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Yes, yes, all right. I follow.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: We're in love.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: In what? Oh, love. So you're in love?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Let me know top you up. He pours more whisky.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I heard a rumour that you want to marry her. That can't be right, can it?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: In this day and age? Is marriage absolutely necessary? Isn't it a bit old hat?  14.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Is it?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: It's a mugs game. I wouldn't go near it if I were you. Anyway you can't marry her. You can't marry her because she's married to me. Unless I divorce her, of course.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: And are you?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Am I what?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Going to divorce her. Or are you really going to make her wait five years? She wants to know.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: To be honest, I can't wait to get rid of her. But I do need to get one or two things straight first. For example, I've never heard of an Italian called Tindle.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: My father's name is Tindolini.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Now that's lovely. Like a little bell. I'd go back to Tindolini if I were you. It suits you.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: You think so?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: So that if and when you marry Maggie she'd be called Maggie Tindolini. She'd get a real kick out of that. Do you act under the name of Tindle or Tindolini?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Tindle.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Why have I never heard of you?  32 33 34 15.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: You will. Before long.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: In spades.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: That sounds threatening.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Does it?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Doesn't it?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Why don't we get down to brass tacks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Brass tacks, brass tacks, yes, why not? This is the way I see it. Come upstairs, I want to show you something. Would you like to try the elevator? It won't make you sick or anything, will it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk to the elevator and get in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stand in silence as the elevator goes up to the top floor. It stops. They get out.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: This is our bedroom. ANDREW uses his remote control. A wall moves, revealing the dressing room.  16.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And this is her dressing room. He opens a wardrobe.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She's left a few dresses here. Can't even be bothered to pick them up. Worth thousands, thousands. That leather coat alone cost two thousand quid. No, you see, the thing is this--sit down--you see, the thing is this--my wife spends money like water. If you're not careful she'll eat you out of house and home. She was born to luxury. Jamaica, the Ritz, the Swiss Alps. I mean, what are you? You're an out of work actor, a part time chauffeur. You're out of your depth, old boy. You're on a hiding to nothing. You think you're broke now but you'll be ten times broker by the time she's finished with you. She'll have your guts for garters.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: She's in love with me.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Never trust in love, chum. Love'1i kick you up the arse as soon as look at you. Take it from me. First it's love, ten minutes later it's contempt.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: That's your own experience, is it?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Certainly not. Observation. Don't forget I'm a novelist. I observe other people. He goes to the window and looks out. MILO watches him-- silence.  17.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What I'm getting at is this. You won't be able to give her what she wants so she'll leave you and come back to me. But I don't want her near me. She's the last thing I want. I've had her up to here. Anyway, I've got a lovely mistress. She runs a Sauna in Swindon. She's my girl. So you see, I want Maggie to stay with you. I want you two to stay together forever, but unless you listen to me the whole thing will be a fucking disaster with catastrophic consequences all round. But I have a solution.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: You won't believe what I'm going to say.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: What are you going to say?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: I'm all ears.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: You know what? I'm beginning to respond to your charm.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Get away.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: It's true.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: I'm really touched.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: You should be. Tell me something else. I bet you didn't expect me to be so intelligent, so quick witted. Did you?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Oh, I did, quite.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Maggie told you, did she?  35 36 37

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: What's your solution?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Vodka. He goes to the door. MILO stands, follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator goes down. ANDREW smiles at MILO.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: It's a close fit, isn't it, for two?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator stops. They get out. INT. ANDREW'S HOUSE’ - BAR AREA - NIGHT ANDREW pours drinks.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Listen. I'm going to make you a proposition. A few years ago I gave her some jewels. Amazingly expensive. Well, I didn't give them to her. I own them. They're insured in my name. But I let her wear them- -on special occasions. They're worth half a million pounds. They spend half their time in the bank or in my safe. At the moment they're in the safe in this house. I want you to steal them. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Steal them?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: What the hell do you mean? rg. 35 36 37  19.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I mean I want you to steal the jewels.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: You want me to steal the jewels.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: I don't get it.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: It's very simple. Steal them. Sell them abroad. Live happily ever after with Maggie. I'll claim the insurance money--they'1ll have to pay up. I'll have got rid of my wife and I'll be as happy as a pig in shit and you can keep Maggie in the manner to which she has become accustometi. Sounds like a fair bargain to me.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: You want me to take part ina scummy little plot to defraud your insurance company? Is that it?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Scummy? I think it's quite elegant.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: What do you think I am? I mean, what the fuck are you actually talking about?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Real facts.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: This is a joke.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: No it isn't.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: It's also a trap.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: A trap?  20.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Yes, it's some kind of trap. You think I'm a fool?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Well, are you?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Anyway, it doesn't hold up.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: You say they're worth half a million pounds?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Correct.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Well, you'd only get a fraction of that--fram any fence.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I've already contacted a friend of mine in Amsterdam. He'll give you £400,000 tax free. Think of it. £400,000 tax free.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Why would he do that?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Because when you steal the jewels you also steal the receipts. So he'll have the title to the jewels as well as the jewels themselves. So when he sells them he'll get the full value. Get it? Think about it. Take your time. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: And why would you do all this?  21.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Listen. Under my crooked exterior I'm a simple honest man. What I've said to you is true. I swear it. I want to get rid of my wife. But I want it to be solid--permanent. I don't want her on my back. I want her to stay on your back.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: This is a frame up.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Frame up? How?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: You want to destroy me. You want to see me in jail. You get me to do this and then shop me to the police.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: No, no. Tf I shop you you'll shop me. So we'd both end up in jail. No, listen. I take a strictly moral position in all this. My wife is an adulteress. She should actually be stoned to death. But anyway, it's up to you. Make up your own mind.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Are you asking me to trust you?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I don't give a fuck if you trust me or not. This is a very simple proposition. You have an expensive woman and no money. If you want to keep her--steal the jewels.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Why don't you steal the jewels and give them to me?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Don't be silly. The burglary has to look real. The house has to be broken in to.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Well, why don't you break into it?  22.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: For Christ's sake. I'm in it. How can I break into it? I live here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MILO walks to the window. He looks out. ANDREW watches him.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: (slowly) Ok. If I were to agree to do this, would you agree to the divorce?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Why would I agree to the divorce if you're both walking away with £400,000?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: She wants a legal settlement. She wants pazt of your estate.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Greedy.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: It's legal justice.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Never trust legal justice. You know what legal justice is? It's farting Annie Laurie down a key hole. Listen. £400,000 tax free. All yours. Cash. Why don't you stop pissing about?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: But--wait a minute--you get £500,000--from the insurance.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Sure I do. All right. I'll be frank. I need it. Cash flow. Stocks and shares going down the drain. Get me? It's quid pro quo. You do me a favour--I do you a favour. And you keep the woman. MILO sips his drink.  23.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: OK. Let's make a deal.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: What deal?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: I break in, I steal the jewels and you agree to the divorce. That's the deal. Otherwise fuck it. That's another quid pro quo. But you have to shake on it. ANDREW stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: (slowly) All right. I shake on it. Here's my hand. They shake hands. Silence. -

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: OK. OK. So what do I do?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: You break in. See that skylight? It's the only window in the house the burglar alarm doesn't touch. You get in there.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: It's pretty high up.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: You climb a ladder.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: I'm not very good at heights.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: You can do it. Honestly. I know you can.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: I think you're putting me on.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Oh, come on. Behave like a man. A man of action. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You don't have to be a hairdresser for the rest of your life. You can be free, independent, and look after the woman you love. He goes to a cupboard and takes out two pairs of earphones with microphone attachments.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Put these on. I use them to give my gardener his instructions. MILO looks at the earphones.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Put them on?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Put them on. You put yours on and I'il put mine on. Like this. They both put on the earphones. » ANDREW (CONT'D) That's it. Actually they suit you. Now what you do is this. You go outside. There's a shed across the lawn. In that shed is a ladder. You put the ladder up against the house and climb up it. I'll direct you-- through the earphones. You with me?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Yes. But I'm anxious and frightened.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Trust me.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: But I don't.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Trust me. All will be well. Just follow my advice. It's got to look real. It's got to convince the imsurance people and the police. See what I mean?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Maggie never told me you were such...a manipulator. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: MILO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She told me you were no good in bed but she never told me you were such a manipulator.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: She told you I was no good in bed?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Oh yes.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: She was joking. I'm wonderful in bed.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: I must tell her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk back into ANDREW's study. There is a bank of TV screens on a wall/series of picture boxes on the laptop. ANDREW presses a button and images of the interior and exterier of the house come up on all the screens.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: There's the shed. Just across the lawn. Go into the shed and get the ladder.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Get the ladder?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Get the ladder. By the ladder there's a pair of gardening gloves. Put them on. Also by the ladder there's a hammer. Carry the hammer up the ladder. Break the window with the hammer. Then you reach in and lift the latch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MILO walks back out into the main room, by the back windows and looks at the skylight directly above.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. You've forgotten a major item.  26.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Once I'm in, how do I get down? How do I get down to floor level?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Oh, didn't I tell you? So sorry. He point high up the wall.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You see that metal rung up there. That's an electric ladder. When you come through the window, stand on the ledge. I'll press a button and the ladder will descend. You get on it and climb down.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Let me see it descend.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Let me see it come down. Now.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Sure. ANDREW presses the button. The ladder begins to extend and comes down.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You see? Easy as pissing.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have a funny feeling that I'ma cunt.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Of course you're a cunt. But so what? You'll end up a wealthy man. Obey the rules. Just obey the rules.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: My rules. Get the ladder. They stare at each other. MILO leaves the room. ANDREW pours himself a drink and lights a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the screen MILO approaches the shed and goes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MILO inside the shed. He looks at the ladder and down at the hammer. He finds the gloves and puts them on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANDREW is smoking. On a screen MILO comes out of the shed with the ladder and the hammer. ANDREW speaks into his mike.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Can you see the skylight?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Place the ladder against the wall.  4g 50 51 52 53 54 55 28.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On another screen MILO can be seen placing the ladder against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Extend the ladder.

dialogues.speaker: OK.
dialogues.text: He extends the ladder. On the screen the ladder can be seen reaching the skylight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The internal electric ladder goes up the wall and disappears into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANDREW is watching the screen.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Climb up the ladder.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Why am I doing this?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Climb up the ladder.  56 57 58 59 60 61 29. On the screen MILO can be seen climbing up the ladder. He slips, regains his balance.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Watch your step.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Jesus. Jesus Christ.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Keep calm.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: I'm going to die.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Never! But don't stop! Don't look down! Keep going. He watches MILO very tentatively climbing up the ladder.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now. OK. You're at the window. Smash it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MILO smashes the window with the hammer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANDREW walks into the main room and looks up at the skylight. MILO is halfway through the window. He looks down. He is caught between jagged glass. He chips it off with the hammer. It falls into the room. He very carefully climbs in and finally manages to stand on the ledge.  30.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Fantastic!

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Where's the ladder?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: What ladder?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: The ladder! Where's it gone?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: You're right. Where has it gone? It's got a mind of its own, that ladder. Wait a minute. ANDREW presses a button. Nothing happens.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh dear. It's not working. This fuse has always been a bit dodgy. He presses the button again.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No, it's not working.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: It's not working?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: There seems to be--what's the word-- a problem. But don't worry. I'll call the electrician in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: In the morning? What about now?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: No, no. He's in bed. You know country people. Early to bed, early to rise. He's a very nice chap though. His name is Norman. Charming wife. She's called Debbie. Three delightful kids. Oh God, I've suddenly remembered--he's on vacation. He's taken the family to Bermuda.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: wall feet

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: When

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: So I'm stuck up here for the rest of my life?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Have patience. Fatience. Stoicism. That's what's called for. Works wonders. Oh, wait a minute. I've just remembered. There's an emergency button up there--on the wall. See it? looks at the wall and finds the button.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's it. Silly of me. Forgot all about it. Anyway, press it and all will be well. presses the button. The ladder comes out of the and descends but the foot of the ladder stops six from the floor. steps on to the ladder and carefully climbs down. he gets to the bottom rung he looks down.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Is this as far as it will go?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Jump ! jumps.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: (holding his leg) Christ!

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Wonderful!

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: I've broken my leg.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Don't be silly. Listen. You were wonderful. Maggie would be proud of you. I'm lost in admiration. remains on the floor massaging his leg.  32.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: I've just had a heart attack.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Let me give you a hand.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: I don't need it. He throws ANDREW off.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: You've got guts. I'm really impressed.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: I thought I was going to die.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: You will. Don't worry.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: You were playing with me. You're a sadist.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: No, no. It was just a little game. That's all. I thought it might amuse you.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: You did, eh? OK. So what the fuck do I do now?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: You open the safe.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Where is it? How do I open it?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. You don't know where it is. You have to find it. You have to look for it. Where is it? Start in the bedroom. They walk to the elevator and get in.  62 63 33.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: How're you feeling?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: OK. All right.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Excited?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Quite, yes.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: You're a cool customer. I like that. The elevator arrives in the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: OK. Open drawers. Open the wardrobe. Throw things about. Go on. You're looking for the safe. You know it's here somewhere. Play it for real. MILO pushes dresses aside and peers into the wardrobe.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Kick the place to death. You're a desperate man. MILO looks around the room. There are a number of small paintings on the walls.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Safe's are always kept behind paintings, aren't they? He lifts a painting from the wall. There is no safe. He throws the painting at the wall.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: That's my Picasso! What are you doing?  64 34.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: I'm a desperate man. Isn't that what you said? ANDREW picks up the Picasso and strokes it.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: My poor Picasso. The man's a barbarian. MILO looks at the painting.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: That's no Picasso. It's a fake. MILO walks towards another painting.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: That's my Matisse! MILO looks at the painting. » MILO Bollocks! He lifts the painting from the wall. There is no safe. He throws the painting against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: MILO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where is this fucking safe?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Open that sideboard. MILO goes to the sideboard

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: It's locked.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Kick it to death. MILO kicks the sideboard, winces with pain. The sideboard remains locked.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is where I hear you.  35.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: You hear me?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes. I'm asleep in my study. That's where I sleep these days. Can't sleep in the bed without my wife, you see. So I hear you. I come into the bedroom. I find you.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: And then?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I attack you.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Like this. ANDREW hits him in the stomach.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And like this. He hits him again in the stomach.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Christ! ANDREW throws another punch. MILO sidesteps and hits ANDREW in the stomach.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Jesus, that hurt.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: So sorry.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: All right. Take out your knife.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: I don't have a knife.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I do. He opens the desk drawer and takes out a knife.  36.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look. You threaten me with this knife.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: You're threatening me.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: No no. I am you. I'm playing you. This is what you do. You want to know where the safe is and what the combination is so you terrorize me with this knife. He pokes MILO with the knife.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Take it easy. He pokes MILO again.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: You can see I'm ruthless. I mean, I'm obviously unpredictable. I'm probably a killer. I'm certainly very dangerous. But you're obstinate.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Me, or you?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: No, you're me, I'm you. Get it? That jewellery is worth a lot of money. You won't give in. So I take out my gun--I'm still you, by the way. He takes a gun from the desk drawer.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And just to make it clear that I mean business I show you I know how to use the gun. He shoots at the photograph hanging on the wall of Maggie and himself in the swimming pool. It smashes.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bulls eye.  37. He shoots at the other photograph hanging on the wall of Maggie and himself in the Lake District. It smashes.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bulls eye. So finally you give in. You're terrified. You show me where the safe is. He leads MILO to a fish tank.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's behind that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He presses a button. The fish tank descends into the floor. A safe is revealed.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There you are. Magic. So you're so frightened you tell me the combination. 1911 9 4. Go on, open it.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. Am I me now? Or am I you? Or are you still me?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: No, you're now you. I'm now me. Open the safe.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: (muttering) 191194.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: It's our wedding day. 19th November, 1994. MILO dials the combination, opens the safe and takes out the box containing the jewellery. He opens it. Antique jewellery, diamonds, rubies etc.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Jesus!

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: What do you think?  38.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: They're quite...beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Put them in your pocket.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: That's what I said. MILO puts the jewels in his pocket. He looks at ANDREW. ANDREW is still holding the gun.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: OK. So far so good. Well, you'd better give me the address of that fence.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: What fence?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: The fence in Amsterdam.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Oh yes. That fence.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Listen. Do you mind putting that gun down?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: It's pointing directly at me. I'm not very happy about it.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Look. Is this a game?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: This is the real game. The real game has just begun.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: What's the real game?  39.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: You and me. You defenceless, me with a gun. This is the end of the jewellery story, you see.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Oh is it?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I enjoyed it though.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: I'm not enjoying this.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I don't blame you.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: What's it all about?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Come on. Buck your ideas up. Did you really think I would let you have my wife and the jewels? You're joking.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: You've been leading me up the garden.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Right up. Stand in the centre of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MILO does so. ANDREW turns the lights out, leaving one spotlight on MILO.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Listen, wait a minute. Before we go any further--there's something I must tell you.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Maggie respects you.  40.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Yes. She often says you're a man of true integrity. That you're a really decent guy.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: She's right. I am a really decent guy.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: I believe it.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Yes, she's quite right, I ama really decent guy.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: I know you are. I know you are. And that's what she says. She admires your mind.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: She admires my mind.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Yes. Your mind excites her.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Sexually?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Oh very. Your mind excites your wife sexually.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: What about my bedy?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Sorry? What?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: My body. What akout my body?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: What about it?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: What about my body? What does she say about my body?  41.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Do you know, I don't think she's ever mentioned it.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: You're a prick.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: My prick? Where does my prick come into it?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I can guess where your prick comes into it. But I wasn't talking about your prick. I just called you a prick.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Oh thanks.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: But you know what you are now though? *

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: You're a dead duck.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Oh yes. You see this is how the story goes. To the police. I found you in my house. You threatened me with a gun. You opened the safe, found the jewels, put them in your pocket. But I managed to grab the gun as you were looking at the jewels. There was a struggle. The gun went off. I suddenly realised you were dead. That I had shot you. I suddenly realised you were dead.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: You're going to shoot me?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: What do you think?  67 42.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I planned all this, you see, from the word go. I've always longed to have an intimate chat with a hairdresser, particularly a hairdresser who is fucking my wife.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: I'm not a hairdresser.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Yes you are. So I thought a little fun would be good for my health. A little game. You see, what you forget is that my wife is mine. She belongs to me. I'm her husband. So what you did was this. You invited yourself here to attend your own death.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: (shivering) Don't do it. Listen. Don't do it. Don't shoot. Please. Don't shoot me. Please. I'll just go away-- quietly. I'll just get into my car and go. That's all. You'll never see me again. Ok? Don't shoot. Don't use that gun. Please. You're crazy. No--you're not crazy. You've just got things wrong. Totally. I don't want your wife. I hate women. You understand? I hate women. I hate your wife. You've absolutely no reason to be jealous. Women are not my scene. I'd rather do it with a dog, or a goat, or a boy I knew at school. His name was Dooley. I called him Dolores. I hate women. Honestly. God's honour. Do you believe in God? ANDREW shoots him. MILO falls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close up on MILO's face. ANDREW goes over to MILO and looks down at his body.  68 69 70 71 72 73 74 75 43. He takes the jewels from his pocket. He puts the jewels into the safe and closes the safe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes into his study.

dialogues.speaker: MONITOR
dialogues.text: Moonlight on the monitors/laptop

dialogues.speaker: MONITOR
dialogues.text: Moonlight in the grounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANDREW opens his fridge, takes out a bottle of champagne and a tin of caviar. He opens the champagne, spreads the caviar on a biscuit, sits, and eats. He looks at a screen.

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY CAMERA
dialogues.text: MILO lying prone in the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MILO is lying on a bed. It appears to be a death bed. MILO's eyes are closed. The room is full of flowers. Maggie bends over him and kisses him on the lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BMW driving between an avenue of trees.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Shut up

dialogues.speaker: PRISONER
dialogues.text: I was only--

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Shut up! I'm asking the questions not you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BMW driving through the street. It stops at roadworks. A red light. An arm comes through the open window and taps the side of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TV.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: How long have you known him?

dialogues.speaker: PRISONER
dialogues.text: I don't know him.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: You don't know him?

dialogues.speaker: PRISONER
dialogues.text: Never met him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The security monitors.

dialogues.speaker: MONITOR
dialogues.text: BMW coming up the drive.  82 83 84 85 45.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANDREW sees the car. He stands and turns the television off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BMW parking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANDREW looking at the BMW parking on the security monitor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The back of a Man at the door. He rings the bell. The door opens.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Andrew Wyke?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Yes. The Man takes out a card and shows it to ANDREW.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Detective Inspector Black. New Scotland Yard. Eddie Black. I'd like a word with you.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: A word?

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: That's right. Black is a thick set man. Dark hair, thin moustache.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: What about?  46.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Can I come in?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Yes, of course. Of course. They go in.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Like a drink?

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Got any beer?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Beer, beer. Yes, sure. He goes to the fridge, takes out a beer and pours. BLACK sits.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: You're the writer. You write crime books.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: I've read a couple. Right on the button. ANDREW gives BLACK a beer and pours himself a vodka.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: That's a great compliment. Cheers.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Cheers. How do you know so much about it?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Villainy. Crime. Horror.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Imagination. Imagination.  47.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Clever.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I do my best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLACK looks up at the skylight.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: I see you've got a broken window up there.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Tropical storm--the other night. Bit of a hurricane. Terrifying. A great branch blew off from one of the big trees out there. It flew through the air and went right through my skylight. As you see. Act of Gad.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Had it in for you, did he?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: God.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Oh yes. He's always been a vicious bastard. Shall I tell you what God's trouble is?

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: He has no father. No family roots. Rootless. Nowhere to hang his hat. Poor bugger. I pity him.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: That's a very interesting philosophical speculation.  48.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I'm so glad you think so. Hey, I've suddenly realised something.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: You're a well known detective. I've seen your picture in the paper. You're very popular in the media.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Do you want to know my opinion of the media?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Journalists are a bunch of prickteasing cocksuckers.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Sorry--isn't that a contradiction in terms?

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Is it?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Anyway, you're quite celebrated, isn't that right?

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: What for? I've forgotten.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: I catch sex criminals, perverts, homicidal maniacs.  49.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: What do you do with them once you've caught them?

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: I generally cut their balls off.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I see. So how can I help you? He leads BLACK into his study.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The light falls during the course of this scene.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Yes, I think you can help me. I think you can.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: How? ~

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: I'm looking into a disappearance.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Disappearance?

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Man called Tindle. Milo Tindle.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Sorry. I didn't get the name. What was it?

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Tindle.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Tindle, Tindle. Uh huh. What about him?

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Do you know him?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Know him? Absolutely not.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: You mean you've never met him?  50.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Never. Never heard of him.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: That's funny.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: why?

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Well, he was staying at the Red Lion in the village. He mentioned to the landlord that he was coming to see you, three nights ago. He hasn't been seen since. His bag is still in his room, shaving kit, all that.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Coming to see me?

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: He mentioned it to the landlord? Why would he mention such a thing to the landlord?

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Well, you're a famous writer. You're well known in the district. So how can you help me on this?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: No one came to see me. I've no idea who this man is. I know nobody called Tindle.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: You don't eh?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: What are you, a joker?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: What do you mean?  51.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: I'm mean you're pretty quick on your feet. You should have been a ballet dancer. I can just see you doing pirouettes. Ever worn a pair of tights?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Not me.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: They'd suit you. He looks around. Walks back into the main hall.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nice house.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Thanks. «

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Design it yourself?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: It's 18th century.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: No no. I meant this. The inside.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: That was my wife.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Oh your wife. Is she here, by the way?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Popped up to London?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: She's not here.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: She's an interior decorator then?  90

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Something like that.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: It's a great gift, isn't it? You're a lucky man. BLACK takes out a cigarette and lights it.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Got an ashtray? ANDREW gives him a plate.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm ready for another beer.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes. ANDREW gets the beer and gives it to BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: A man was passing your house three nights ago. He says he heard shots.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Passing my house? How could he do that? This is private property.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: He was taking a short cut. You know what it's like in the country. I think he's a poacher. Anyway, he says he heard shots.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: What kind of shots?

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Gun shots.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Fantasy.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Really?  Pause. 53.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Codswallop. Bullshit. Who is this man? Are you sure he exists?

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Oh, he exists all right. Oh by the way, cheers.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Cheers.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: I want to ask you another question.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Ask.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: You do know your wife is living in London with another man?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: That's my business. My private life is my private business.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Do you know the name of this man?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Why should I answer these questions?

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Well you don't have to. But you'd be better off if you did.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I don't know the man's name. I've never asked.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: So you admit that your wife is living in London with another man?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes. So what?

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Well I can tell you the man's name. It's Tindle. Milo Tindle.  54.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Is it?

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Yes. The bloke who's disappeared. The bloke who said he was coming to see you.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: We found this note in his room in the pub. He reads the note aloud.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: "I look forward to meeting you. Come to the house Friday evening. Six thirty. Wyke." He gives ANDREW the. note.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is this your handwriting? ANDREW looks at the note.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: It is.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Do you remember writing this note?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: How could I forcet?

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: You forgot earlier. You said you didn't know him. You said you'd never heard of him.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I was lying.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Lying to the police. That'll get you nowhere. I don't understand you, mate. Honest. You're a clever man. You write clever books. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you've made a right balls up of this one, haven't you?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Have I?

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Tindle came to see you three nights ago.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I knew him as Tindolini.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Oh yes?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: He had an Italian father.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Get away.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Yes. They're a traditional Italian hairdressing family.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Is he a hairdresser himself?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I think he is.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: He didn't come all the way down here to do your hair, did he?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Oh not at all, not at all.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: So what did you two do when you got together?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: We played a game.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: A game?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: A game with a knife and gun.  56.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: A lethal game?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: No no. Just a bit of fun, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: OK. A bit of fun. He comes to see you, you play games with a knife and gun. Three shots are fired and then he disappears. So where is he?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Probably cuddling my wife.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: That's the one thing he's not doing.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: I've seen her. He was nowhere in sight. She's an anxious woman. She knew he was coming to see you, you see. In fact she insisted that he came to see you, as I know you know. She thinks you may have killed him. She thinks you're round the bend. She thinks you're a very dangerous man.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Me? She's joking.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: So tell me, between ourselves, did you kill him?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I'll tell you exactly what I did. I pretended to kill him. I shot him with a blank. I frightened the shit out of him. Your man was right. Your spy--or whatever he was. There were three shots. The first two were real, the third a blank. He was terrified. When I shot him he fainted. When he woke up I gave him a drink and a pat on the bum. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He left the house, his tail--if you want to call it that--between his legs. I haven't seen him since.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: You gave him a pat on the bum?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Metaphorically.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: You gave him a metaphorical pat on the bum?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: How did he take it?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pat.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Oh he's a good sport. He told me it was game set and match to me.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: So this guy had a sense of humour? Is that what you're saying?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Oh yes. Oh yes, he left this house with a twinkle in his eye.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: So, tell me--whaz was the point of all of this?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Humiliation. It's nice to see your wife's lover a shivering, frightened, fucking wreck in front of you. But as a matter of fact I quite liked him. I found him attractive. I thought we might become good friends. The shortest way to a man's heart is, as I'm sure you know, humiliation. It binds you together.  58.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: You found him attractive?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I was trying to stand in my wife's shoes, in a manner of speaking. I was trying to find out what attracted her to him.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: And did you?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Oh yes. He was really terribly sweet. I could see why she fancied him.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: I could see why he fancies her. I thought she was very tasty myself.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Really? +

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Oh yes. Sumptuous. Ready for action.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Is that so?

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Oh yes. I mean, I'm an experienced detective. So guess what I detected?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: What ?

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: That she's in love with her own body. It makes her dizzy with excitement.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: You detected this in five minutes?

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Well, thirty-five. Or lets call it forty-five. Perhaps even fifty- five. Or even a bit longer.  59.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: You stayed for tea?

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: And cakes. Yes, must be funny for you to know your own wife is being given a good going-over by another man on a regular basis.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: A good going-over? I don't quite follow you.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: You don't?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: It's not a phrase I'm familiar with.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: It means being fucked.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Oh, you mean like in sexual intercourse?

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Yes, the old one two. In like a lion and out like a lamb.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I must say you have a great gift for language. Did you learn it at school?

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: The hard school. Family life.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: But you keep cheerful.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: You've got it. I keep cheerful. I've got an optimistic nature. Well you have to if you're a policeman. Otherwise you'd go mad. No, I'11 tell you what keeps me going. The chase. The thrill of the hunt. And the sudden shafts of bright light. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: BLACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: For instance, when I was talking to your wife--very attractive woman-- wonderful legs--she was crossing them at a time I remember--she suddenly said you had a murderous nature--that really made my nose twitch.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Itch?

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Twitch, mate. Twitch. So I'm looking at you and wondering what you've done with the body. What have you done with the body? Where's the body? Come on. I need to know. Where's the body? What have you done with the body?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: There's no body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't fuck about. Don't bullshit me. I won't stand for it. Where's the body. In the house? Or did you shift it?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: There is no body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLACK stands, looks about him and walks around the room. He walks to the wall and examines it.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Eh, look at this. You've got holes in your wall. They're bullet holes. Live bullet holes.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I fired two live bullets to set up the trick and one blank to complete it. It was a game. I told you. I played it to the hilt. Not worth playing a game if you don't play it to the hilt.  61.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: So you're saying the third shot was a blank?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: What's this? BLACK bends and touches the floor.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Blood.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Blood?

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Dried blood.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Here. Right here. Some of it hasn't even dried, it's still damp.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: It's impossible.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: This is blood, chum. Whose blood is it?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: It's impossible. It was a game. It was a blank.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: No no. It was a game with real bullets and real blood.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: This is a carve up.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Lets see what else is new around here.  He goes to a cupboard and opens it.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hello, what's this? He reaches into the cupboard.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You've got a shirt, jacket and trousers screwed up at the back of your cupboard. Very negligent of you mate. Unless they're not yours. He examines them.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No, I don't think they're yours. I think they belong to Tindle. You say he left the house after you shot him?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Yes. -

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Naked?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I don't know...how those clothes got there.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: So you made him strip before you shot him? Part of the humiliation, was it? No. The thing is this. It might have started as a game but it got out of hand. The third shot was live, it killed him. So where's the body?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: I didn't kill him. He's alive.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Bollocks. BLACK moves very close to ANDREW and peers into his face,  63.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're a joker all right, aren't you? A real joker. Come on. We're off to the station.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: There's something very wrong here.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Dead right. I'll tell you what you are. You're fucked. BLACK takes him by his arm.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're under arrest. He takes him into the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ~» ANDREW Jesus Christ.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: Don't struggle chum. I'll have you for breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: There's something very wrong here.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: You're up shit creek, Wyke. You're up shit creek without a paddle. They exit the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stare at each other. BLACK suddenly laughs. He takes off his wig. He takes out his contact lenses, rips off his moustache, takes off jacket and shoulder holster, opens shirt, shows padding. He smiles at ANDREW. It is MILO.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Look at you. You're all of a quiver. Who's the dead duck? (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: MILO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're the dead duck. I've just sucked you in and blown you out in little bubbles.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The security monitors.

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY MONITOR
dialogues.text: MILO lying prone. His eyes suddenly open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANDREW stands and finishes his glass of champagne. INT. ANDREW'S HOUSE” - MASTER BEDROOM -NIGHT - FLASHBACK ANDREW comes into the room and leans over MILO.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: You all right, old boy? MILO stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All right? Just a bit deaf I suppose. They do make such a noise. Did you think you were dead? (he laughs) No you're not dead. It was a blank. Do you remember? I shot you with a blank. I just wanted to give you a fright. It was a joke. I was joking. Did you think I was really going to kill you? No no. It was a game, that's all. Like a drop of brandy? ANDREW goes and pours brandy, he gives it to him.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here you are. What a good sport you are. A really good sport. Did I give you a fright? So sorry. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (he laughs) You fainted, you see. You thought you were dead. Drink the brandy and you'll find you're alive. Dead men don't drink brandy. MILO drinks. ANDREW raises his own glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheers.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: You know, it's funny, you're absolutely right, I really did think I was dead.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: That's what I wanted you to think.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: You play a tough game.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: It's the-only game worth playing.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Well listen, I'm grateful to you-- for not killing me.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: It was a practical decision, that's all. I mean, if I killed you I would have to get rid of the body, bury it in the garden or something. Too exhausting and not very efficient.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Yes, I see that.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Anyway, here you are, fit asa fiddle.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Yes. Thanks. Listen. I think I'll pop off, grab a cheese sandwich somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Oh my goodness, you're right, you must be starving. How thoughtless of me. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'1l tell you what, I've got a pretty shrewd idea there are a couple of cold sausages in the fridge. Been there for years. Like one?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: No thanks. But thanks for the brandy. It came in handy. They both laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MILO taking off padding.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: It's you!

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: It's me all right. « ANDREW You bastard. You shit. You stinking bastard.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Just a little game, Andrew. Just a little game. I thought it might amuse you.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: You're a total shit.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: I know I am.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: But you're also a genius.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: I know that too. He starts to put on his own clothes.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: When did you do all this? The clothes in the wardrobe? The blood?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: The blood belongs to a pig's liver.  67.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: But when did you do it? How did you do it?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: I did it last night. I used that ladder. I heard you snoring.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Does Maggie know about all this? About your Inspector? Was it her idea? How much does she know?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: She knows nothing about it. Entirely my own idea. This is a game between us, old boy. Between you and me. Had to get some revenge, you see. Don't forget I'm half Italian. We go in for revenge. After all, you frightened the life out of me, deliberately. You fired two live bullets into the wall and then pointed the gun at me. And then you fired. I don't like guns. They kill you.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: OK. So what does this make the score? You've had your revenge, so what do you reckon? One set all?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: No no, you're way ahead. I just teased you with my Inspector. Gave you a few goose simples. But you frightened me to death. So we're a long way from one set all. I may be three games up in the second set, but you won the first six love.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Oh, by the way, I spoke to Maggie. I told her all about you. She loved it.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Loved what?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: That I frightened the life out of you. That you pissed your pants. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That you actually fainted. She said: "You mean he actually fainted?" I said: "Dead out. He was scared shitless. He went out like a light." She laughed so much I thought she was going to burst. Oh and incidentally, she's coming back to me.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Oh, is she?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: That's right. You know what she said about you?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: She said "Faint heart never won fair lady". « MILO Is that a fact? Listen. I want to show you something. Go into your study and sit down.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Go into my study?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: And sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANDREW does so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Though the open study/bookcase door, ANDREW and MILO can see each other.

dialogues.speaker: MILO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Keep the wall open. Watch me. MILO puts on the shoulder holster. He presses a button on the wall. The ladder comes down. He grasps the last rung and swings his legs onto the ladder. He then climbs halfway up the ladder.  1o1 69.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: It's late at night. You're reading under the lamp. Read something.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Read a book. ANDREW picks up a book and opens it.

dialogues.speaker: MILO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's late at night. You're reading a book. You hear something. You look up. It's me, jumping off the ladder. MILO jumps off the ladder. He takes the gun out of the holster and walks tewards the study.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANDREW stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: MILO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You see me with this gun. You're caught--like a rat in a trap. You stare at the gun. You're paralysed. ANDREW sits staring at him.

dialogues.speaker: MILO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I've come for the jewels. Where's the safe?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: What jewels?

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: The jewels. Where's the safe?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: You know where it is.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: No I don't.  70.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: You don't? MILO. Don't fuck me about. I mean it. Get up. ANDREW remains seated.

dialogues.speaker: MILO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You think I'm joking? You think this gun isn't real? He shoots at a vase, it smashes.

dialogues.speaker: MILO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Get up. ANDREW stands.

dialogues.speaker: MILO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where is it?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: Upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Well, let's go upstairs. Not in the elevator. Up these stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk to the stairs. ANDREW hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: MILO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Get up these stairs or I'll ram this gun right up your arse. MILO prods him with the gun. ANDREW stumbles and then runs up the stairs followed by MILO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter the bedroom. ANDREW leads MILO to the fish tank.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
dialogues.text: It's behind the fish tank. I have to press this button to shift the tank,  71.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Then press it.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREW
